results.title: A Potter's world
results.brief_description: The craftsmanship of Bernard Leach who, after a number of years in the East, established a pottery in Cornwall. The influence of the Orient on his work is indicated.

results.title: A Poem by Edward Lear: The Owl and the pussy-cat
results.creator_credit: John Korty, Contemporary Films and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description: Uses animation to portray the children’s poem ‘The Owl and the Pussy-cat’, by Edward Lear, in which the owl and the pussycat jump into their pea-green boat and sail out to the sea. Narrated by Cyril Ritchard. Suitable for lower primary level.

results.title: A Planter of colonial Virginia (1740-1765)
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and ERPI Classroom Films
results.brief_description: Produced in collaboration with the Williamsburg Restoration, this film aims at an authentic portrayal of life in 18th century colonial Virginia. Williamsburg was the centre of the economic, social and political life of the colony, which depended mainly on the products of the tobacco plantations in the area for its wealth. The life of the slaves and indentured servants is studied, in conjunction with the current legal system, together with the social customs of the plantation owners and their families, and the music, architecture, and costumes of the period. The methods of manufacture, means of transport, and the medical practices of the day are also presented.

results.title: A Place to stand
results.brief_description: A letter-boxed single-screen version of this dynamic award-winning multiple projection presentation. Produced by the Province of Ontario, for their stand at Expo ‘67. Up to nine different projectors are used of varying shapes and styles to display the manifold virtues of Ontario’s agricultural, mining, manufacturing and maritime industries, before examining the environmental features and recreational possibilities.

results.title: A Place to live
results.creator_credit: Claire Taplin and United Nations Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Man builds - man destroys”.
Human struggle for shelter is as old as the struggle for food. The film examines the problems to be faced in the future of human settlements. How can they be solved in industrialised urban areas like New Zealand, and how different are the requirements of rural areas in a developing country like Indonesia. A significant feature of the film is the on-going comparison between Djkarta and Auckland - with some interesting changes 21 years on.

results.title: A Place to live
results.creator_credit: Lee R. Bobker and National Social Welfare Assembly
results.brief_description: Stresses the need for old people to live in properly run homes for the aged. Suggests that in most cases living with their children - particularly when there are young grandchildren - will not work.

results.title: A Place to live
results.brief_description: Lake Ellesmeer south of Christ Church is a popular breeding ground for many water birds. Every year some 5000 black swans nest on the lake’s shores. White swans multiply less prolifically. Mallard ducks, gulls, terns, wading birds including stilts and herons, all inhabit the Ellesmeer district. Canada geese fly down from the hills in December and January for their molting season. As more wet lands are drained these birds are in danger of losing their home.
